EXISTING STRUCTURES
────────────────────────────
### Shared Smelting Furnaces Automation Network
Consists of two stone furnaces positioned at (0.0, 0.0) and (5.0, 0.0), each paired with dedicated burner‑inserters and wooden chests that regulate the input and output of smelting operations.

### Iron Ore Mining Automation Setup
Consists of a burner‑mining drill located at (–15.0, –50.0) linked to a nearby wooden chest at (–13.5, –51.5). This setup is integrated into a transport‑belt network that distributes the mined ore.

### Steam Power Generation System
Centered on a boiler at (8.0, 20.5) (currently out of fuel) with connection points at (8.5, 18.5) and (8.5, 22.5). A series of steam engines are placed at:
• (0.5, 9.5)  
• (18.5, 11.5)  
• (1.5, 13.5)  
• (13.5, 14.5)  
• (19.5, 14.5)  
• (22.5, 18.5)  
• (17.5, 20.5)  
• (12.5, 21.5)  
• (4.5, 23.5)  
Additionally, an extra steam engine remains unplaced due to severe congestion in the boiler area and obstruction in the buildable zone near (8.5, 22.5).

### Automation Research Lab
Features a lab configured for automation science pack research; however, it continues to experience unstable power connectivity.

### Electrical and Transport Infrastructure
Comprises an integrated network of electrical poles organized into electricity groups, multiple belt groups for managing transport belts, and pipe groups that bundle fluid pipes—ensuring coordinated flow of power, materials, and fluids.

### Offshore Pump and Fluid Network
Consists of an offshore pump at (0.5, 30.5) that feeds water into the fluid system through a connected network of pipes.

ERROR TIPS
────────────────────────────
• Persistent Extra Steam Engine Placement Issue  
  – The extra steam engine remains unplaceable because the area around the boiler at (8.0, 20.5) is severely congested and the vicinity of (8.5, 22.5) is obstructed.  
  – Tip: Perform a comprehensive manual inspection of the boiler zone and its connections. Remove or reposition interfering burner‑inserters, transport belts, and any overlapping entities. Alternatively, relocate the extra steam engine to a less congested area or alter the boiler layout to create sufficient clearance.

• Fuel Supply and Source Item Shortages  
  – Multiple burner‑inserters and the burner‑mining drill are frequently flagged as “out of fuel” or “waiting for source items.”  
  – Tip: Ensure that fuel sources are positioned adjacent to burner‑powered entities and that fuel inventories are maintained to continuously supply these machines.

• Steam Engine Connectivity and Fluid Input Issues  
  – Numerous steam engines report statuses such as “not connected to power network” and “no input liquid,” indicating problems with electrical wiring and fluid piping.  
  – Tip: Review and reconfigure electrical and fluid connections to guarantee that every steam engine is properly linked to the power network and receives the necessary liquid input.

• Laboratory Power Instability  
  – The automation lab continues to suffer from unstable power connectivity.  
  – Tip: Reevaluate the placement and wiring of nearby electrical poles to improve and stabilize the lab’s power supply.

• Overall Layout Congestion  
  – The boiler region exhibits a clutter of overlapping and misaligned burner‑inserters and transport belts, which restricts the placement of additional entities.  
  – Tip: Reorganize the spatial layout around critical connection points to eliminate overlaps and free up buildable zones, thereby facilitating proper placement and interconnection of structures.
